lull.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to make someone feel calm or as if they want to sleep
lull.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The hum of the tyres on the road lulled her to sleep.
lull.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to make someone feel safe and confident so that they are completely surprised when something bad happens
lull.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The police lulled me into believing that they did not suspect us.
Earthquakes here are rare and this has lulled people into a false sense of security  (=made people think they were safe when they were not).
lull.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a short period of time when there is less activity or less noise than usual
lull.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: a brief lull in the conversation
lull.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a period of time during which there is very little buying, selling, spending etc taking place
lull.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The bond market is slipping into a year-end lull.
Buying has hit a seasonal lull.
an expected short-term lull in demand
lull.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to make someone feel confident and trusting so that they can be deceived or are not prepared for what happens
lull.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Some investors were lulled into a false sense of security (=made to feel that things are safe when they are not).
